Award.AwardTitle: Pathways to Preparing Future Mathematics Faculty to Transform Undergraduate Mathematics Teaching and Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Graduate students in mathematics are often called on to teach sections of introductory courses ranging from college algebra, to precalculus, to calculus. In this project a team of mathematicians and mathematics education researchers are developing a sequence of courses and associated activities that support Ph.D. students in mathematics to adopt a scientific approach both to their teaching and to evaluating the effectiveness of the underlying curriculum. The intellectual merit of this effort lies in its use of previously developed research-based student and teacher materials that have been documented to transform precalculus and calculus teaching and learning. Based on this prior work the investigating team is creating a model education certificate program for mathematics graduate students that is envisioned to transform their teaching practice. Concurrent with these teaching experiences, students complete a sequence of courses and seminars in which they read select publications, review materials, and design and conduct small-scale research studies of student learning. These combined program components lay the groundwork for producing mathematics Ph.D. students who are prepared to take leadership roles in improving the teaching and learning of undergraduate mathematics. The project is exercising its broader impact both by engaging the faculty to change the culture and departmental infrastructure in the PI's own institution, and by serving as model for other departments of mathematics who can incorporate the education certification program into their graduate offerings, thus supporting pre-professional faculty development of their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pathways Precalculus innovation emerged from 20-years of research into the teaching and learning of precalculus and beginning calculus. The innovation includes research scaffolded lessons (both in-class and online), research developed instructional resources, and mathematically focused professional development. The Pathways Precalculus innovation has been adopted by 14 mathematics departments. Data from these sites reveal highly significant gains in student learning (as assessed by validated concept inventories), with approximately 75% of Pathways students receiving a course grade of A, B or C (McNicholl, Frank, Hogenson, Roat & Carlson, 2020). Studies of Pathways graduate student instructors' teaching revealed significant shifts toward more conceptually focused and student-centered instruction (Carlson & Bas Ader, 2019; Rocha & Carlson, 2020).  

The Pathways Precalculus research produced 11 dissertations and over 30 research publications. This collection of studies have: i) advanced knowledge of learning and teaching key ideas of precalculus that are foundational for learning calculus; ii) advanced knowledge of the mechanisms for supporting precalculus teachers to implement conceptually oriented precalculus instruction; iii) guided the design and refinement of research scaffolded student learning experiences in precalculus mathematics; iv) advanced knowledge of the mechanisms for scaling the Pathways precalculus innovation to mathematics departments; v) supported over 500 precalculus instructors in providing more conceptually oriented and coherent precalculus instruction; and vi) provided conceptually oriented precalculus instruction to tens of thousands precalculus students. The Pathways Precalculus innovation led to significantly greater gains (than prior approaches to precalculus instruction) in student learning, success, and mathematics course taking for tens of thousands precalculus students.   

There have been many attempts to address student attrition and low learning gains in precalculus level courses with few approaches leveraging research on learning and teaching the course's key ideas. This has led to the perpetuation of curriculum that focusses on methods for simplifying and solving, prior to supporting student curiosity, interest, or understanding of precalculus ideas. In contrast, Pathways cognitive studies (Carlson et al., 2002; Carlson, Oehrtman and Engelke, 2010; Moore & Carlson, 2012; Carlson, Madison & West, 2015; Carlson & Moore, 2015; Kuper & Carlson, 2020; O'Bryan & Carlson, 2016; Musgrave & Carlson, 2016; Tallman, 2014; Thompson & Carlson, 2017) have revealed ways of thinking and understandings that are necessary for learning calculus and solving applied problems in precalculus. A key finding of this collection of studies is that student ability to define function formulas and graphs (that are meaningful to the student) can be fostered by engaging students with tasks and applets that support their conceptualizing quantities in the problem context and considering how pairs of quantities are related and change together. This approach to teaching precalculus concepts supports students in becoming more confident and competent mathematical thinkers, making mathematics learning more accessible to a broader population of students.

Our study of precalculus teachers' instructional practices prior to their full participation in the Pathways innovation revealed a predominant focus on instructor led demonstrations of methods for obtaining answers. Instructors were further observed constructing incoherent drawings and expressing weak meanings of fundamental precalculus ideas (Bas Ader & Carlson, 2021; Carlson & Bas Ader, 2019; Musgrave & Carlson, 2017; Tallman & Frank, 2018; Teuscher, Moore, and Carlson, 2016). Interviews with precalculus instructors and mathematics graduate student assistants further revealed their having no prior experience reflecting on the learning or teaching of precalculus ideas. This finding may explain the predominant focus on procedural teaching in precalculus mathematics.  

Our research into precalculus instructors' teaching practices revealed greater gains in student learning when instructors implemented conventions for engaging their students in conceptualizing quantities in a problem context and considering how pairs of quantities are related and change together. The Pathways conventions (described in more detail in Carlson, O'Bryan, Rocha, & Lock, in press) support students in shifting away from approaching problems by carrying out memorized procedures, to their constructing personal images of the quantitative structure described in a problem context, as a foundation for constructing function graphs and formulas. Consistent implementation of the Pathways conventions for conceptualizing and representing how pairs of quantities are related and change together led to more students developing strong meanings for key precalculus concepts (e.g., rate of change, linear, exponential & quadratic growth, periodic functions).

Pathways researchers identified the following variables as influencing a mathematics department's decision to adopt and scale the Pathways innovation: i) departmental administrators valuing student understanding of key concepts, in addition to procedural fluency; ii) instructor participation in an initial 2-3 day professional development workshop focused on developing instructors' understanding of what knowing and learning precalculus ideas entails; iii) instructors participate in weekly professional development led by a local course coordinator who engages Pathways instructors in advancing their conceptions of how key ideas of upcoming lessons are learned; iv) local site data is collected and documents gains in student learning and success, and v) departmental administrators are supportive of Pathways instructors.
